choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

questions.text: Maternal deaths per 1,00,000 women in the reproductive age group is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal mortality rate

 

The maternal mortality rate refers to the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age (usually between 15 and 49 years) in a given time period. This rate considers the entire population of women in the reproductive age group and not just those giving birth. It helps in assessing the risk associated with pregnancy and childbirth among all women in the reproductive age group.

 

PPH is the most common cause of Maternal mortality in India

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perinatal mortality rate: This rate measures the number of stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life per 1,000 total births. It does not specifically pertain to maternal deaths.

 

Option B. Maternal death rate: Although similar in terminology, this option is not used commonly and does not fit the precise definition provided for maternal mortality metrics.

 

Option D. Maternal mortality ratio: This ratio measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period. It specifically relates to deaths due to complications during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy but does not include the entire reproductive age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maternal mortality rate measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women in the reproductive age group, focusing on the general population of women of reproductive age rather than only those who have given birth.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation, there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb, and the anterior aspect of the chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36%

 

The Rule of Nines, also known as Wallace's rule, is used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. This method divides the body into sections, each accounting for approximately 9% (or multiples thereof) of the TBSA.

 

  • Left upper limb: Each upper limb is considered to account for 9% of the TBSA.
  • Right upper limb: Similarly, the right upper limb accounts for another 9%.
  • Anterior aspect of chest and abdomen: The anterior trunk, which includes the chest and abdomen, is considered to be 18% of the TBSA.

 

To calculate the total percentage of burns:

 

  • Left upper limb: 9%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Anterior chest and abdomen: 18%

 

Adding these together: 9%+9%+18%=36%

 

Thus, the patient has burns covering 36% of their body surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following bony structures is present behind the marked area? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lesser wing of sphenoid

 

The pterion is a point on the side of the skull where several bones meet, including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The lesser wing of the sphenoid is one of the bones that contributes to the formation of the pterion. It's an important landmark because it's located just behind the pterion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post clivus: The clivus is a bony ridge on the occipital bone, and it is located at the base of the skull. The "post clivus" isn't a commonly used term in anatomy, and it's not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option C. Sella turcica: The sella turcica is a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone where the pituitary gland is located. It is situated more toward the center of the skull, behind the eyes and nasal cavity, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option D. Carotid canal: The carotid canal is a passage in the temporal bone that houses the internal carotid artery. It is located deeper within the skull, closer to the middle ear, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

1. Frontal bone

2. Squamous part of the temporal bone

3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone

4. Parietal bone

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient who is used to taking alcohol for the last 25 years suddenly presented with agitation and confusion. There were gait abnormalities. On enquiry, the person gave a history of alcohol withdrawal for 3 days. Identify the condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens

 

The scenario described is most consistent with delirium tremens (DTs), a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. DTs usually occur 2-3 days after cessation of heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption and can include symptoms such as agitation, confusion, tremors, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity. The patient’s history of chronic alcohol use, coupled with recent withdrawal, supports this diagnosis. Gait abnormalities, confusion, and agitation are hallmark symptoms in this context.

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, often due to thiamine deficiency, presents with a classic triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic "GOA"). However, the absence of ophthalmoplegia and the presence of withdrawal symptoms make delirium tremens a more fitting diagnosis in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine deficiency: Thiamine deficiency can lead to Wernicke’s encephalopathy, which presents with global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. However, the history of alcohol withdrawal and the symptoms presented align more with delirium tremens.

 

Option C. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as visual disturbances, metabolic acidosis, and neurological deficits, which are not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Ethanol poisoning: Ethanol poisoning usually presents with signs of intoxication, such as slurred speech, incoordination, and respiratory depression. This does not align with the history of withdrawal and the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a life-threatening condition that occurs during alcohol withdrawal, characterized by confusion, agitation, tremors, and often hallucinations

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

 

  1. Eonism: a. Sexual gratification by cross-dressing. This term is used to describe individuals who derive sexual pleasure from dressing in clothes traditionally worn by the opposite gender.
  2. Frotteurism: b. The act of rubbing one's genitals against a non-consenting person, usually in a crowded place, such as public transport. It is considered a paraphilic disorder.
  3. Necrophilia: c. Sexual stimulation by corpses. This is a rare and extreme paraphilia where individuals are sexually aroused by deceased bodies.
  4. Algolagnia: d. Sexual gratification in inflicting or suffering pain. This can involve either sadism (inflicting pain) or masochism (receiving pain) as part of sexual activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism is sexual gratification by cross-dressing, frotteurism involves rubbing genitals against a non-consenting person, necrophilia is sexual stimulation by corpses, and algolagnia involves sexual gratification from inflicting or suffering pain.

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning except? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Luminous vomit

 

Luminous vomiting is a feature of yellow phosphorus poisoning, not arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raindrop pigmentation: This is a characteristic skin finding in chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Option B. Peripheral neuritis: Peripheral neuritis is a common neurological manifestation of chronic arsenic exposure.

 

Option C. Mees line: Mees lines (transverse white lines on nails) are indicative of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features seen in chronic arsenic poisoning:

 

1. Peripheral neuropathy (neuritis):         

It can occur in Arsenic , Thallium , Mercury, and Lead.                                  

Lead: Mainly motor, little bit sensory neuropathy                                                     

Arsenic, Thallium, mercury: mainly sensory, little bit motor neuropathy 

 

2) Skin symptoms:

- Hypopigmentation initially

- Rain Drop Pigmentation as shown below

 

 

- Peculiar skin rash – resembles Addison’s disease , Fading measles rash

- Hyperkeratosis of palms & soles as shown below:

 

3) Nails: Aldrich Mees Lines

Transverse whitish lines on nails (seen is Arsenic, and Thallium)

 

 

 

4) Hair: Alopecia seen in Mercury, Arsenic, Thallium (Mnemonic: Hair on MAT)

 

5) GIT: Vomiting , Diarrhoea , pain abdomen

 

6) Liver: Jaundice , Hepatomegaly , Fatty liver , Cirrhosis

 

7) Blackfoot disease: Coagulation in Peripheral blood vessels leading to Gangrene of periphery

 

8) Malignancy of almost any body part

questions.text: A diabetic patient's blood sample was taken in a grey top vacutainer. Which of the following is added for the correct estimate of blood glucose? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride

 

Explanation:

 

For accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients, the blood sample is collected in a grey top vacutainer containing sodium fluoride. Sodium fluoride acts as a glycolysis inhibitor, preventing the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells. This ensures that the glucose levels in the sample remain stable until the analysis is performed, providing an accurate representation of the patient's blood glucose concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium citrate is used as an anticoagulant and is present in blue top vacutainers, which are typically used for coagulation studies and not for glucose estimation.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is an anticoagulant used in lavender top vacutainers, which are commonly used for complete blood count (CBC) and other hematological tests, but not for glucose estimation.

 

Option D. Heparin is an anticoagulant found in green top vacutainers, which are used for various biochemical tests, but not specifically for glucose estimation in diabetic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride, present in grey top vacutainers, inhibits glycolysis and prevents the breakdown of glucose, ensuring an accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients.

questions.text:
HDI is calculated by using ? [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Life expectancy at birth
  2. Mean years of schooling
  3. Gross national product
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) All three


The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite index used to measure the overall achievement of a country in three basic dimensions of human development:

 

  1. Health: Measured by life expectancy at birth, which reflects the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if current mortality rates continue to apply.
  2. Education: Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or older and expected years of schooling for children entering school. This represent knowledge, enrolment ratio.
  3. Living Standards: Measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, expressed in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP) in US dollars.

 

These components together provide a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development, allowing for comparisons across countries.

 

Educational Objective:
 

HDI is calculated using three components: life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, and Gross National Income per capita. These factors represent health, education, and living standards, respectively.

 

  • HDI range – 0 to +1
  • HDI (India) – 0.644 (Rank 134)
  • HDI (Switzerland) – 0.96 (Rank 1)

choices.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm
Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.text: What leads to the detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attachment of ATP to myosin head

 

Binding of ATP to the myosin head is what leads to the detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament during muscle contraction. The process of muscle contraction involves several steps where ATP plays a crucial role:

 

  1. Attachment of ATP: An ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.
  2. Hydrolysis of ATP: The myosin head, which has ATPase activity, hydrolyzes ATP into ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi). This hydrolysis provides the energy required for the myosin head to return to its high-energy, cocked position.
  3. Cross-bridge formation: The myosin head binds to a new position on the actin filament.
  4. Power stroke: The release of ADP and Pi from the myosin head triggers the power stroke, where the myosin head pivots and pulls the actin filament, causing muscle contraction.
  5. Repeat cycle: The cycle repeats as long as ATP is available and calcium ions are present to keep the binding sites on actin exposed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissociation of ADP and Pi: This is involved in the power stroke, not in the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option B. Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm: This leads to muscle relaxation by causing the tropomyosin to cover the binding sites on actin, not directly to the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option C. Conformational change in Troponin T: This occurs when calcium binds to troponin, allowing tropomyosin to move away from the binding sites on actin, not directly related to detachment of myosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which allows the myosin head to release from the actin and prepare for another cycle of contraction.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison – liquefactive necrosis

 

Management – Emergency → stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation – conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment – usually after 3-6 months → elective reconstruction → esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

choices.text: MTP can be done only to reduce risk of mother
MTP can be carried up to 24 weeks

questions.text: A victim of sexual assault with 22 weeks of gestation is brought for MTP. Which of these is a true statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MTP can be carried up to 24 weeks

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) can be performed up to 24 weeks of gestation under certain circumstances, including cases of sexual assault, rape, or incest, which are recognized as valid grounds for termination under the MTP Act. In cases of pregnancies resulting from such trauma, the law allows MTP up to 24 weeks with the opinion of two registered medical practitioners.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One Doctor is involved: This is incorrect because for MTP after 20 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one.

 

Option B. MTP can be done only to reduce the risk of the mother: This statement is incorrect because MTP is also allowed under other circumstances, such as cases of rape, fetal anomalies, or when the continuation of pregnancy could cause significant physical or mental harm to the woman.

 

Option D. MTP not allowed after 20 weeks: This is incorrect as the MTP Act allows for termination up to 24 weeks under specific conditions, including cases of sexual assault.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP can be legally carried out up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, fetal anomalies, and other specific conditions with the opinion of two doctors.

questions.text: Implantation of the embryo takes place how many days after fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8


Implantation of the embryo typically starts around 5 to 6 days after fertilization and is usually completed by 8 to 9 days. After fertilization, the embryo undergoes several stages of development, including cleavage and blastocyst formation. The blastocyst travels down the fallopian tube and reaches the uterus by around day 5. It then begins to attach to and invade the uterine lining, completing the implantation process by around day 8. Therefore, 8 days is the most accurate answer representing the completion of the implantation process.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Implantation of the embryo begins around day 5 to 6 and is completed by day 8 to 9 after fertilization.

choices.text: Start ART if CD4 <200
Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks
Start ATT and ART simultaneously

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks


In HIV patients with tuberculosis (TB), it is crucial to start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first to reduce the mycobacterial load before initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART). This approach helps to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), a life-threatening condition due to massive cytokine response triggered by a rapid increase in CD4 count., which can occur if ART is started too early. The general recommendation is to start ART by 2 weeks -2 months, after ATT initiation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Starting ART only if CD4 <200: does not address the immediate need for TB treatment.

 

Option B. Starting ART before ATT: can lead to IRIS.

 

Option D. Starting both therapies simultaneously:  increases the risk of IRIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with TB, start ATT first and then initiate ART after 2 weeks-2 months duration.

questions.text: A baby who can ride a tricycle, can walk alternate steps on stairs, he cannot do hopping. What is the age of the baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.5 years

 

A 3-year-old child can typically ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet. The ability to ride a tricycle is usually developed around the age of 3, as "tri" refers to three, indicating this milestone. Walking up stairs with alternate feet is another skill that a 3-year-old can manage. However, hopping on one foot usually develops around the age of 4. Since the child in question cannot hop yet, it indicates the child is likely not yet 4 years old. Therefore, the best answer is 3.5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child who can ride a tricycle and walk up stairs with alternate feet but cannot hop is typically around 3.5 years old.

questions.text: A teacher presented with complaints of hoarseness of voice. On examination, bilateral swelling was noted on anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vocal nodule 

 

Clinical history suggests a most probable diagnosis of vocal nodule

 

Vocal Nodules (aka Singer's nodule/Teacher's nodule)

 

Pathogenesis – Trauma → submucosal oedema & hemorrhage → hyalinization & fibrosis

 

Site: appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cord, at junction of anterior 1/3rd & posterior 2/3rd of vocal cord (Bilateral) as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma

 

Clinical feature – Hoarseness, Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation are other common symptoms.

 

Treatment - Voice rest, Speech therapy, Micro laryngeal surgery if persistent

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal Polyp is an exophytic lesion with thin mucosa, caused by sudden shouting. Presents with Hoarseness of voice, Diplophonia (double voice).

 

 

Option C. Vocal Cyst are retention cysts occur in false vocal cords.

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema is Diffuse collection of oedema fluid in sub-epithelial space, MC in smokers. On examination, saddle-bag appearance of vocal cords on laryngoscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are common in individuals who frequently use their voices intensely, and they require a combination of vocal rest, speech therapy, and possibly surgical intervention to manage effectively and prevent recurrence.

choices.text: Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis
Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal wall rigidity. Exploratory laparotomy was done and the following was found. What would you do in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Simple primary repair

 

The scenario described suggests that the patient has a perforation of the small bowel, as indicated by the image showing a hole in the intestine. Abdominal wall rigidity is indicative of peritonitis, which results from the leakage of intestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity due to a perforation. The provided images and description align with a small bowel perforation, likely in the jejunum or ileum.

 

In cases of small bowel perforations, particularly when the perforation is small, the standard management is a simple primary repair. This involves suturing the perforation directly, which is often sufficient to manage the defect without the need for more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis:
This is typically reserved for cases where the perforation is large, there are multiple perforations, or when the perforation is associated with a pathological condition like a stricture like in tubercular perforation. In the case described, a simple primary repair is usually sufficient.

 

Option B. Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch: This procedure, known as an omental patch or Graham's patch, is more commonly used for duodenal ulcers, not for small bowel perforations.

 

Option D. Purse string suture: This technique is not commonly used for repairing small bowel perforations. It is more suitable for specific types of perforations or fistulas but not typically indicated in the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For small bowel perforations, particularly in the jejunum or ileum, the primary approach is often a simple primary repair. This involves directly suturing the perforation and is usually effective for managing small perforations.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Derailment

 

Formal thought disorders refer to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought, rather than the content of thought.

 

Here, the association between two successive thoughts is disturbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obsession: It refers to recurrent, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts. It's more related to possession than the form of thought.

 

Option C. Delusion: It is a false belief that is unshakeable and cannot be explained on the basis of a person's social and cultural background.It is a disorder of thought content.

 

Option D. Thought insertion: It is the belief that certain of one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather are inserted into one's mind. This is also a possession of thought, not its form.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Formal thought disorders pertain to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought. Derailment, loose associations, neologisms are examples of a formal thought disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 10

questions.text: A young male came with GI complaints like malabsorption, diarrhea. Cutaneous examination noted itchy lesions on the skin with blistering. On histopathology, cryptitis and flattened villi were noted. His condition improved with a gluten-free diet. What is the specific antibody in this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tissue Transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3)

 

The patient's symptoms, including gastrointestinal complaints like malabsorption and diarrhea, combined with itchy skin lesions and histopathological findings of cryptitis and flattened villi, are indicative of dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition is closely associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

 

The specific antibody associated with dermatitis herpetiformis is tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3). This antibody is primarily responsible for the characteristic skin lesions seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibodies: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are a group of autoantibodies that target components of the cell nucleus. They are commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions but are not related to celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3) antibodies is a hallmark of dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition associated with celiac disease. This autoimmune response is triggered by gluten ingestion and manifests with both gastrointestinal and cutaneous symptoms.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

  • The image shows swan neck deformity seen in RA.
  • Characteristic Deformities of Hand and Foot In RA:

 

 

 

 

Finger deformities in RA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand. Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma. Scleroderma is a severe CTD characterized by vascular, immune and fibrotic changes in the skin and internal organs. While tethering of the skin is the clinical hallmark of SSc, many patients develop musculoskeletal symptoms also. Manifestations may include rheumatic complaints ranging from arthralgias to frank arthritis, contractures and tendon friction rubs. Articular involvement contributes to disability and impaired quality of life. All joints may be affected, although the fingers (in particular the MCP and PIP joints), wrists and ankles predominate. As the disease progresses, there is tethering and contracture of the joints with impairment of movement and function.

 

 

Calcinosis and contracture of joints

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. JC virus: Incorrect, while JC virus can cause infections in transplant recipients, its occurrence is less frequent compared to CMV during this specific post-transplant period.

 

Option C. BK virus: Incorrect, although BK virus is a concern in renal transplant patients, particularly for its role in causing nephropathy, it is not as predominant as CMV in the early months following transplantation.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr virus: Incorrect, Epstein-Barr virus also poses a risk for post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders in transplant recipients, but it is less commonly the primary pathogen within the first few months post-transplant compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:


Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation, showcasing the importance of monitoring and managing CMV to prevent its common presentations and complications in this vulnerable period.

questions.text: A patient has had his molar teeth extracted, following which he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lingual nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The innervation of the tongue is divided into three parts: anterior two-thirds, posterior one-third, and posterior most part.

 

The anterior two-thirds of the tongue is derived from the first pharyngeal arch, innervated by the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, supplies general sensation (pain, temperature, and touch) to this part of the tongue. However, taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).

 

The posterior one-third of the tongue is derived from the third pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which carries both general and taste sensation.

 

The posterior most part of the tongue is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X), which carries both general and taste sensation.

 

Tongue development:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. The glossopharyngeal nerve innervates the posterior one-third of the tongue, not the anterior two-thirds.

 

Option B. Hypoglossal nerve: Incorrect. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to the tongue muscles and does not carry sensory fibers.

 

Option C. Inferior alveolar nerve: Incorrect. The inferior alveolar nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve that supplies the lower teeth, gingiva, and lower lip, but not the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (trigeminal nerve), supplies general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.text: A covid patient was discharged from hospital & was recovering at home. In order to join back his duties, he himself started taking excessive multivitamin supplements and he developed symptoms of nerve sensations- tingling sensations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the associated symptoms seen in this patient?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B6 Excess

 

Vitamin B6 Excess: Correct Answer. Excessive intake of Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) can lead to neuropathy, manifesting as sensory changes such as tingling or burning sensations, especially in the hands and feet. This is due to its effect on the nervous system, where it can cause nerve damage when taken in high doses over a prolonged period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D Excess: While excessive Vitamin D can lead to toxicity, its symptoms primarily include hypercalcemia, leading to symptoms like nausea, vomiting, weakness, and frequent urination. It is not typically associated with peripheral nerve sensations or tingling.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 Excess: Vitamin B12 is a water-soluble vitamin, and its excess is usually excreted in the urine. It is not commonly associated with toxicity, and symptoms like tingling sensations are more typically associated with B12 deficiency, not excess.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 Excess: Excess of Vitamin B3 (Niacin) can cause "niacin flush," characterized by skin flushing, itching, and gastrointestinal symptoms. It is not typically associated with neuropathic symptoms like tingling sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Excessive intake of pyridoxine can lead to toxicity, which can cause a range of symptoms and health problems. The recommended daily intake of pyridoxine for adults is 1.3-1.7 mg/day, and the tolerable upper intake level (UL) is set at 100 mg/day for adults. Exceeding the UL can lead to pyridoxine toxicity.

 

Symptoms of pyridoxine toxicity can include:

 

  1. Sensory neuropathy: Numbness, tingling, and pain in the extremities, which can progress to loss of sensation and muscle weakness.
  2. Ataxia: Difficulty with coordination and balance.
  3. Photosensitivity: Increased sensitivity to sunlight, which can cause skin rash and sunburn.
  4. Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  5. Impaired glucose tolerance: High doses of pyridoxine can interfere with glucose metabolism and lead to impaired glucose tolerance.
  6. Cognitive impairment: High doses of pyridoxine can cause confusion, irritability, and depression.
  7. Seizures: Rarely, high doses of pyridoxine can cause seizures.

 

Pyridoxine toxicity is rare and usually occurs only with prolonged use of high-dose supplements (usually over 1,000 mg/day) over a period of time. 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 543-544

questions.text: Identify the type of injury given in the image below:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contusion

 

The image above shows a contusion.

 

  • A contusion, or bruise, is caused by a direct blow to the body that can cause damage to the surface of the skin and to deeper tissues as well depending on the severity of the blow.
  • It causes rupture of capillaries of the skin leading to the bruise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abrasion: Abrasion is a superficial injury where the skin is scraped off, usually due to friction against a rough surface. It does not typically involve deep tissue damage or significant bruising.

 

Option C. Laceration: A laceration is a tear or a jagged wound caused by blunt trauma. It usually has irregular margins and can vary in depth and severity.

 

Option D. Stab wound: A stab wound is a penetrating injury caused by a sharp object such as a knife. It is characterized by a small entry point and can vary greatly in depth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contusions, also known as bruises, are caused by blunt trauma that ruptures capillaries beneath the skin, leading to discoloration. They differ from abrasions, lacerations, and stab wounds in their mechanism of injury and appearance.

choices.text: 90% is associated with ANCA positivity
30% is associated with Hepatitis B

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 30% association with Hepatitis B

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis predominantly affecting medium-sized arteries, often associated with Hepatitis B in about 30% of cases. The association with Hepatitis B is significant because the virus can trigger immune complex deposition, contributing to vascular inflammation and damage characteristic of PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing inflammation of large vessels: This is incorrect because PAN specifically affects medium-sized, not large vessels. Large vessel vasculitis includes conditions like Giant Cell Arteritis and Takayasu Arteritis.

 

Option B. Patient has hypogammaglobulinemia: This is incorrect; PAN is often associated with hypergammaglobulinemia due to chronic immune activation, not hypogammaglobulinemia.

 

Option C. 90% is associated with ANCA positivity: This statement is also incorrect. Polyarteritis nodosa is typically ANCA-negative; the presence of ANCA is more characteristic of other forms of vasculitis such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

choices.text: Serum ceruloplasmin levels
Serum copper levels

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin levels

 

The image of the eye, showing a possible Kayser-Fleischer ring, along with symptoms of hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration, strongly suggests Wilson disease. Wilson disease is a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism. The initial screening test in suspected cases is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels, as ceruloplasmin is the primary copper-carrying protein in the blood, and levels are typically reduced in Wilson disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum copper levels: This test is used to further support the diagnosis after abnormalities in ceruloplasmin levels are noted. Total serum copper is typically low in Wilson disease, but free copper is elevated due to the low ceruloplasmin levels.

 

Option C. Enzyme assay: Not relevant for Wilson disease, which involves a defect in copper transport rather than an enzyme deficiency.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: Also not relevant, as Wilson disease is related to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child presenting with hepatitis and neurological symptoms, the presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring strongly suggests Wilson disease. The first diagnostic step is to measure serum ceruloplasmin levels.

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive technique that involves the insertion of a needle through the stomach wall under ultrasound guidance to obtain a sample of pancreatic tissue. EUS-guided biopsy has a high diagnostic accuracy and is considered the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma as it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI-guided biopsy: Is a technique that uses magnetic resonance imaging to guide the insertion of a needle to obtain a tissue sample. This technique is not commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its low accuracy.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves the insertion of a laparoscope through small incisions in the abdomen to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample. Laparoscopic biopsy is a more invasive option than EUS-guided biopsy but may be used when other methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option D. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Involves the insertion of a needle through the abdominal wall to obtain a tissue sample from the pancreas. This technique is less commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to the risk of complications such as bleeding and infection.

 

Overall, EUS-guided biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation:

 

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). According to their guidelines:

 

  • The fasting blood glucose cut-off value for diagnosing GDM during a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is >92 mg/dL.

 

This value is used as part of a comprehensive assessment, including 1-hour and 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. The IADPSG criteria for GDM diagnosis include:

 

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: ≥180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: ≥153 mg/dL

 

If any one of these values is abnormal, the diagnosis of GDM can be made.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. >95 mg/dL: This is not the IADPSG recommended cut-off for fasting blood glucose. It is higher than the specified cut-off value for diagnosing GDM.

 

Option C. >106 mg/dL: This value is significantly higher than the recommended cut-off. It exceeds the threshold for diagnosing GDM according to IADPSG guidelines.

 

Option D. >90 mg/dL: While this value is close, it is slightly below the IADPSG recommended cut-off of >92 mg/dL for diagnosing GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus according to IADPSG is >92 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 326, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A G3P2L1NND1 presents at 37 weeks with previous 2 LSCS with primary active HSV. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)


In a patient with a history of two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS) and active primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at 37 weeks of gestation, an elective LSCS is the safest approach. Active HSV infection is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of neonatal herpes transmission, which can lead to severe complications in the newborn. A classical cesarean (vertical incision on the upper uterus) is not indicated here because the LSCS provides a safer and more appropriate route without the additional risks associated with classical cesareans, such as increased bleeding and uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Classical cesarean: A classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment and is generally reserved for cases where lower segment access is challenging, such as in preterm deliveries or certain uterine anomalies. It is not warranted here and would increase future obstetric risks.

 

Option C.  VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean): VBAC is contraindicated in this case due to active HSV infection and the risk of neonatal transmission. Additionally, VBAC is not recommended after two previous cesareans, especially when other complications like active infection are present.

 

Option D. IOL (Induction of Labor): Inducing labor is contraindicated in patients with active HSV due to the risk of viral transmission to the baby during delivery. This approach would pose significant risks without any benefit in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Active herpes simplex virus infection during labor is an indication for a cesarean section to prevent neonatal transmission.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change given in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Marbling

 

  • The picture above shows a postmortem change called Marbling.
  • In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tattooing: Refers to punctate abrasions from unburned gunpowder particles, seen in gunshot wounds, not related to postmortem changes.

 

Option C. Lividity: Also known as livor mortis, this refers to the settling of blood in dependent parts of the body, causing a purplish-red discoloration.

 

Option D. Filigree burns: Caused by electrical burns, producing a lace-like pattern on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Marbling is characterized by the appearance of greenish-black streaks on the skin due to the formation of sulfmethemoglobin, typically becoming prominent 24-48 hours postmortem.

questions.text: Which gene is affected in Reiter's syndrome?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HLA-B27

 

Explanation:

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 gene. The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a risk factor for developing Reiter's syndrome.

 

Reiter's syndrome is a type of spondyloarthritis, a group of inflammatory diseases that primarily affect the spine and joints. It is characterized by a triad of symptoms: arthritis (joint inflammation, typically affecting the knees, ankles, and feet), conjunctivitis (inflammation of the eye), and urethritis (inflammation of the urethra).

 

The HLA-B27 gene is a component of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system, which plays a crucial role in the immune system's recognition of foreign substances. The association between HLA-B27 and Reiter's syndrome suggests that the gene may contribute to the development of the condition, possibly by influencing the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA-DR3: This gene is associated with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and Graves' disease.

 

Option B. HLA-DR4: This gene is strongly linked to rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA-DQ8: This gene, along with HLA-DQ2, is associated with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HLA-B27 gene is the primary genetic factor associated with the development of Reiter's syndrome, a type of spondyloarthritis characterized by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis.

questions.text: What alternative drug would you use for cardiac arrest if epinephrine is not effective? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amiodarone

 

Epinephrine and amiodarone are the two main drugs approved by the American Heart Association for the resuscitation of a cardiac arrest patient.
Dose of epinephrine = 1 mg every 3-5 min IV
Dose of Amiodarone = 300 mg IV bolus dose

 

  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug that is used to treat and prevent various types of arrhythmias.
  • For cardiac arrest, amiodarone is particularly recommended for ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.
  • It acts by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial tissue, and it also has vasodilatory effects.
  • The initial recommended dose for cardiac arrest is 300 mg IV push.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasopressin: Vasopressin is a synthetic peptide that stimulates V1 receptors, leading to vasoconstriction. It was once considered as an alternative to epinephrine for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), but more recent guidelines from organizations like the American Heart Association (AHA) have moved away from recommending its routine use in cardiac arrest. This is due to a lack of evidence showing a significant improvement in survival to hospital discharge.

 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks the effects of the vagus nerve on the heart. It increases the heart rate and was previously used in the treatment of asystole and pulseless electrical activity (PEA) cardiac arrest. However, more recent AHA guidelines no longer recommend atropine for routine use in these situations due to lack of evidence for its effectiveness.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Adenosine is a drug that is primarily used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). It works by slowing down the electrical activity in the heart, which can temporarily stop the heart, allowing it to "reset" itself to a normal rhythm. While adenosine can be very effective for its indicated uses, it's not typically used in the setting of cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Amiodarone is an effective alternative drug for cardiac arrest, particularly for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta previa: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marginal

 

Given image shows a Type 2 / Marginal Placenta Previa.

 

Other Options A, C, D are explained in the table below

 

OLDER CLASSIFICATION (BROWNE’S CLASSIFICATION)

 

 

 

NEWER CLASSIFICATION (BASED ON TRANSVAGINALSONOGRAPHY)

 

  1. Placenta Previa: Placenta partially or completely covers the internal os.
  2. Low lying placenta: implantation in the lower uterine segment is such that the placental edge does not reach the internal os and remains outside a 2-cm wide perimeter around the os.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low lying: Type 1 / Low Lying Placenta Previa is when the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment of the uterus but stays away from the internal os.

 

Option C. Incomplete: Type 3 / Incomplete Placenta Previa is when the placenta covers the internal os partially.

 

Option D. Complete: Type 4 / Complete Placenta Previa is when the placenta completely covers the internal os.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marginal Placenta Previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the margin of the internal os but not covering it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284, Williams textbook of Obstetrics  24th edition page 800

questions.text: A patient was presented to OPD with features of collagen vascular disorder. Which of the following deficits is most likely to be associated with defective collagen formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Explanation:

 

Deficiencies in both ascorbic acid and the minerals copper and iron collectively contribute to defective collagen formation. Ascorbic acid deficiency impairs the hydroxylation of collagen, while copper and iron deficiencies affect collagen cross-linking and stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascorbic Acid:  Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) is crucial for collagen synthesis. It acts as a cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, enzymes necessary for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen. Deficiency of Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by weakened collagen and symptoms like bleeding gums and poor wound healing.

 

Option B. Copper and Iron:  Copper is a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, an enzyme involved in the cross-linking of collagen fibers, essential for the strength and integrity of collagen. Iron is also involved in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis. Deficiencies in these minerals can impair collagen formation and structure.

 

Option D. Zinc & Magnesium: While zinc and magnesium are important for overall health and participate in numerous enzymatic reactions, they are not primarily associated with collagen synthesis or cross-linking in the same direct manner as ascorbic acid, copper, and iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post translational modification of collagen on proline and lysine residue is required for its proper hydrogen bond formation and crosslinking which provide strength to collagen fibers. These reactions require vitamin C, copper and iron as cofactors for the enzyme involved in these processes.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

questions.text: Apixaban belongs to which of the following class of drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor Xa inhibitor

 

Apixaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. Other examples of this class of drug includes Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban.

 

It is the DOC for the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT, also for prophylaxis of thrombosis in monovalvular atrial fibrillation (except for severe mitral stenosis where Warfarin is used).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifibrinolytic: Antifibrinolytics, such as tranexamic acid, work by inhibiting the breakdown of fibrin, stabilizing clots. Apixaban does not belong to this class.

 

Option C. Oral direct thrombin inhibitor: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, directly inhibit thrombin (Factor IIa). Apixaban does not inhibit thrombin directly; it inhibits Factor Xa.

 

Option D. Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor: Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as argatroban and bivalirudin, are administered intravenously and inhibit thrombin directly. Apixaban is not administered parenterally and does not directly inhibit thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apixaban is an oral direct Factor Xa inhibitor used for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and thromboembolism in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute gout

 

The patient presents with acute pain and swelling in the left great toe, a common presentation of acute gout. Despite normal serum uric acid levels, the clinical presentation and the findings from the synovial fluid analysis point towards acute gout.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Acute Pain and Swelling of the Left Great Toe: This is characteristic of acute gout, especially involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
  2. No History of Trauma: This excludes traumatic causes of joint pain.
  3. Synovial Fluid Analysis Shows Raised Leukocytes: Indicates an inflammatory arthritis.
  4. Normal Serum Uric Acid Levels: In 30-40% of acute gout cases, serum uric acid levels can be normal due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint rather than in the bloodstream.

 

Acute Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints, leading to intense pain and swelling. The first MTP joint is the most commonly affected site. Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, particularly during an acute attack, due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint.

 

Diagnosis Confirmation: The diagnosis of gout is confirmed by joint aspiration and identification of negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudogout: This condition usually presents in elderly individuals and often involves the knee or wrist joints. The presence of chondrocalcinosis on X-ray and the involvement of joints like knee (MC), wrist or MCP joint (NOT first MTP joint) makes pseudogout less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Reactive Arthritis: This condition typically follows a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and involves multiple joints. There is no mention of such a history in this patient.

 

Option D. Septic Arthritis: This condition is usually associated with more severe systemic symptoms like fever and a more aggressive clinical course. The patient's presentation does not match the typical features of septic arthritis.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, especially during an acute attack, and the involvement of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint is highly characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • The provided clinical scenario presents a patient with symptoms of anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an accompanying image displaying hydrops fetalis.
  • These manifestations collectively suggest a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as Fifth disease, which is caused by parvovirus B19.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

 

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

 

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

 

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) in pregnancy leads to subsequent pregnancy loss.

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) by trans placental spread causes fetal damage at all gestational ages. Features are periventricular calcifications, microcephaly, hearing loss, hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and abdominal pain. He reports memory loss and reveals that he works at a battery recycling plant. On examination, a noticeable foot drop in both lower extremities is seen. Laboratory testing shows elevated blood lead levels. Which enzyme is affected in the given scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase

 

The question clearly indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning (elevated blood levels and associated clinical features)

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis through inhibition of multiple enzymes involved in heme synthesis pathway, of which main inhibited enzymes are:

 

  • ALAD (Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase)- Mnemonic ALAD sounds like lead
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
  • Ferrochelatase

 

This leads to increased levels of multiple precursors of Heme production like:

 

  • Protoporphyrin
  • Coproporphyrin
  • δ-amino levulinic acid

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen III: Not directly inhibited by lead. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is involved in the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III.

 

Option C. Uroporphyrinogen I: Not directly involved in lead poisoning. Uroporphyrinogen I is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway but not specifically inhibited by lead.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Not involved in the heme synthesis pathway. This enzyme is part of the metabolic pathway converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective

 

Lead poisoning primarily inhibits the enzyme Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase (ALAD), leading to disruptions in the heme synthesis pathway and accumulation of heme precursors.
